column1: Leeds is the largest city in the county of West Yorkshire in Northern England
column2: approximately 170 miles (270 km) north of central London.  Leeds is the cultural
column3: financial and commercial heart of the West Yorkshire Urban Area
column4: the UK's fourth-most populous urban area with a reported population of 2.6 million in 2013.The city is served by five universities
column5: has the UK's fourth-largest student population and the country's fourth-largest urban economy.It has one of the most diverse economies of all the UK's main employment centres and has seen the fastest rate of private-sector jobs growth of any UK city. It also has the highest ratio of private to public sector jobs of all the UK's Core Cities
column6: with 77% of its workforce working in the private sector. Leeds has the third-largest jobs total by local authority area
column7: with 480
column8: 000 in employment and self-employment at the beginning of 2015. Leeds is ranked as a "High Sufficiency" level city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network.Leeds was a small manorial borough in the 13th century
column9: becoming a major centre for the production and trading of wool in the 17th and 18th centuries
column10: then a major mill town during the Industrial Revolution; wool was still the dominant industry
column11: but flax
column12: engineering
column13: iron foundries
column14: printing
column15: and other industries were also important. From being a market town in the valley of the River Aire in the 16th century
column16: Leeds expanded and absorbed the surrounding villages to become a populous urban centre by the mid-20th century.

column2: Leeds has become the largest legal and financial centre outside London with the financial and insurance services industry worth £13 billion to the city's economy. The finance and business service sector account for 38% of total output with more than 30 national and international banks located in the city
column3: including an office of the Bank of England. Leeds is also the UK's third-largest manufacturing centre with around 1

column5: 000 employees; Leeds manufacturing firms account for 8.8% of total employment in the city and is worth over £7 billion to the local economy. The largest sub-sectors are engineering
column6: printing and publishing
column7: food and drink
column8: chemicals and medical technology. Other key sectors include retail
column9: leisure and the visitor economy
column11: and the creative and digital industries. The city saw several firsts
column12: including the oldest-surviving film in existence
column13: Roundhay Garden Scene (1888)
column14: and the 1767 invention of soda water.Public transport
column15: rail and road communications networks in the region are focused on Leeds; the second phase of High Speed 2 will connect it to London via East Midlands Hub and Sheffield. Leeds currently has the third busiest railway station and the tenth busiest airport outside London. Leeds has a less extensive public transport coverage than other UK cities of comparable size
column16: and is the largest city in Europe without any form of light rail or underground system.

column1: The name derives from the old Brythonic word Ladenses meaning "people of the fast-flowing river"
column2: in reference to the River Aire that flows through the city. This name originally referred to the forested area covering most of the Brythonic kingdom of Elmet
column3: which existed during the 5th century into the early 7th century.Bede states in the fourteenth chapter of his Ecclesiastical History
column4: in a discussion of an altar surviving from a church erected by Edwin of Northumbria
column5: that it is located in ...regione quae vocatur Loidis (Latin
column6: "the region which is called Loidis"). An inhabitant of Leeds is locally known as a Loiner
column7: a word of uncertain origin. The term Leodensian is also used

column1: The name has also been explained as a derivative of Welsh lloed
column2: meaning simply "a place".

column1: Leeds developed as a market town in the Middle Ages as part of the local agricultural economy.

column2: it became a co-ordination centre for the manufacture of woollen cloth
column3: and white broadcloth was traded at its White Cloth Hall.Leeds handled one sixth of England's export trade in 1770. Growth
column4: initially in textiles
column5: was accelerated by the building of the Aire and Calder Navigation in 1699 and the Leeds and Liverpool Canal in 1816. In the late Georgian  era
column6: William Lupton  was one of a  number of central Leeds landowners with a mesne lord  title
column7: some of whom
column9: were textile manufacturers.  At the time of his death in 1828
column10: Lupton occupied the enclosed fields of the  manor of Leeds
column11: his estate including a   mill
column12: reservoir
column13: substantial house and outbuildings.The railway network constructed around Leeds
column14: starting with the Leeds and Selby Railway in 1834
column15: provided improved communications with national markets and
column16: significantly for its development
column17: an east–west connection with Manchester and the ports of Liverpool and Hull giving improved access to international markets. Alongside technological advances and industrial expansion
column18: Leeds retained an interest in trading in agricultural commodities
column19: with the Corn Exchange opening in 1864.

column1: Marshall's Mill was one of the first of many factories constructed in Leeds from around 1790 when the most significant were woollen finishing and flax mills. Manufacturing diversified by 1914 to printing
column2: engineering
column3: chemicals and clothing manufacture. Decline in manufacturing during the 1930s was temporarily reversed by a switch to producing military uniforms and munitions during the Second World War. However
column4: by the 1970s
column5: the clothing industry was in irreversible decline
column6: facing cheap foreign competition. The contemporary economy has been shaped by Leeds City Council's vision of building a '24-hour European city' and 'capital of the north'. The city has developed from the decay of the post-industrial era to become a telephone banking centre
column7: connected to the electronic infrastructure of the modern global economy. There has been growth in the corporate and legal sectors
column8: and increased local affluence has led to an expanding retail sector
column9: including the luxury goods market.Leeds City Region Enterprise Zone was launched in April 2012 to promote development in four sites along the A63 East Leeds Link Road.

column1: Leeds was a manor and township in the large ancient parish of Leeds St Peter
column2: in the Skyrack wapentake of the West Riding of Yorkshire. The Borough of Leeds was created in 1207
column3: when Maurice Paynel
column4: lord of the manor
column5: granted a charter to a small area of the manor
column6: close to the river crossing
column7: in what is now the city centre. Four centuries later
column8: the inhabitants petitioned Charles I for a charter of incorporation
column9: which was granted in 1626. The new charter incorporated the entire parish
column11: as the Borough of Leeds and withdrew the earlier charter. Improvement commissioners were set up in 1755 for paving
column12: lighting
column13: and cleansing of the main streets
column14: including Briggate and further powers were added in 1790 to improve the water supply.

column1: The borough corporation was reformed under the provisions of Municipal Corporations Act 1835. Leeds Borough Police force was formed in 1836
column2: and Leeds Town Hall was completed by the corporation in 1858. In 1866
column3: Leeds and each of the other townships in the borough became civil parishes. The borough became a county borough in 1889
column4: giving it independence from the newly formed West Riding County Council and it gained city status in 1893. In 1904 the Leeds parish absorbed Beeston
column5: Chapel Allerton
column6: Farnley
column7: Headingley cum Burley and Potternewton from within the borough. In the twentieth century the county borough initiated a series of significant territorial expansions
column10: 612 acres (164.35 km2) in 1961. In 1912 the parish and county borough of Leeds absorbed Leeds Rural District
column11: consisting of the parishes of Roundhay and Seacroft; and Shadwell
column12: which had been part of Wetherby Rural District. On 1 April 1925
column13: the parish of Leeds was expanded to cover the whole borough.The county borough was abolished on 1 April 1974
column14: and its former area was combined with that of the municipal boroughs of Morley and Pudsey; the urban districts of Aireborough
column15: Horsforth
column16: Otley
column17: Garforth and Rothwell; and parts of the rural districts of Tadcaster
column19: and Wharfedale. This area formed a metropolitan district in the county of West Yorkshire. It gained both borough and city status and is known as the City of Leeds. Initially
column20: local government services were provided by Leeds City Council and West Yorkshire County Council. When the county council was abolished in 1986
column21: the city council absorbed its functions
column22: and some powers passed to organisations such as the West Yorkshire Passenger Transport Authority. From 1988 two run-down and derelict areas close to the city centre were designated for regeneration and became the responsibility of Leeds Development Corporation
column23: outside the planning remit of the city council. Planning powers were restored to the local authority in 1995 when the development corporation was wound up.

column2: 42% of the population of Leeds lived outside the township
column3: in the wider borough. Cholera outbreaks in 1832 and 1849 caused the authorities to address the problems of drainage
column4: sanitation
column5: and water supply. Water was pumped from the River Wharfe
column6: but by 1860 it was too heavily polluted to be usable. Following the Leeds Waterworks Act of 1867 three reservoirs were built at Lindley Wood
column7: Swinsty
column8: and Fewston in the Washburn Valley north of Leeds.Residential growth occurred in Holbeck and Hunslet from 1801 to 1851
column9: but
column10: as these townships became industrialised new areas were favoured for middle class housing. Land south of the river was developed primarily for industry and secondarily for back-to-back workers' dwellings. The Leeds Improvement Act 1866 sought to improve the quality of working class housing by restricting the number of homes that could be built in a single terrace.Holbeck and Leeds formed a continuous built-up area by 1858
column11: with Hunslet nearly meeting them. In the latter half of the nineteenth century
column12: population growth in Hunslet
column13: Armley
column14: and Wortley outstripped that of Leeds. When pollution became a problem
column15: the wealthier residents left the industrial conurbation to live in Headingley
column16: Potternewton and Chapel Allerton which led to a 50% increase in the population of Headingley and Burley from 1851 to 1861. The middle-class flight from the industrial areas led to development beyond the borough at Roundhay and Adel. The introduction of the electric tramway led to intensification of development in Headingley and Potternewton and expansion outside the borough into Roundhay.Two private gas supply companies were taken over by the corporation in 1870
column17: and the municipal supply provided street lighting and cheaper gas to homes. From the early 1880s
column18: the Yorkshire House-to-House Electricity Company supplied electricity to Leeds until it was purchased by Leeds Corporation and became a municipal supply.Slum clearance and rebuilding began in Leeds during the interwar period when over 18
column19: 000 houses were built by the council on 24 estates in Cross Gates
column22: Belle Isle and Halton Moor. The slums of Quarry Hill were replaced by the innovative Quarry Hill flats
column24: 000 houses were built by private sector builders
column34: 000 sub-standard houses were demolished by the council and replaced by 151 medium-rise and high-rise blocks of council flats in estates at Seacroft
column37: and Brackenwood.Leeds has seen great expenditure on regenerating the city
column38: attracting in investments and flagship projects
column39: as found in Leeds city centre. Many developments boasting luxurious penthouse apartments have been built close to the city centre.

column1: Leeds is located 169 miles (272 km) north-northwest of London
column2: on the valley of the River Aire in the eastern foothills of the Pennines. The city centre lies in a narrow section of the Aire Valley at about 206 feet (63 m) above sea level; while the district ranges from 1
column3: 115 feet (340 m) in the far west on the slopes of Ilkley Moor to about 33 feet (10 m) where the rivers Aire and Wharfe cross the eastern boundary. There are also significant variations in elevation within the city itself. For example
column4: land rises to 198 m (650 ft) in Cookridge
column5: just 6 miles (9.7 km) from the city centre.  The centre of Leeds is part of a continuously built-up area extending to Pudsey
column6: Bramley
column7: Horsforth
column9: Seacroft
column10: Middleton and Morley.Leeds has the second-highest population of any local authority district in the UK (after Birmingham)
column11: and the second-greatest area of any English metropolitan district (after Doncaster)
column12: extending 15 miles (24 km) from east to west
column13: and 13 miles (21 km) from north to south. The northern boundary follows the River Wharfe for several miles (several kilometres)
column14: but it crosses the river to include the part of Otley which lies north of the river.

column1: The city centre is less than twenty miles (32 km)) from the Yorkshire Dales National Park
column2: which has some of the most spectacular scenery and countryside in the UK. Inner and southern areas of Leeds lie on a layer of coal measure sandstones forming the Yorkshire Coalfield. To the north parts are built on older sandstone and gritstones and to the east it extends into the magnesian limestone belt. The land use in the central areas of Leeds is overwhelmingly urban.Attempts to define the exact geographic meaning of Leeds lead to a variety of concepts of its extent

column1: Leeds has a climate that is oceanic (Köppen: Cfb)
column2: and influenced by the Pennines. Summers are usually mild
column3: with moderate rainfall
column4: while winters are chilly
column5: cloudy with occasional snow and frost. The nearest official weather recording station is at Bingley
column6: some twenty kilometres away at a higher altitude.July is the warmest month
column7: with a mean temperature of 16 °C (61 °F)
column8: while the coldest month is January
column9: with a mean temperature of 3 °C (37 °F). Temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) and below −10 °C (14 °F) are not very common but can happen occasionally. Temperatures at Leeds Bradford Airport fell to −12.6 °C (9.3 °F) in December 2010 and reached 31.8 °C (89 °F) at Leeds city centre in August 2003. The record temperature for Leeds is 34.4 °C (94 °F) during the early August 1990 heatwave. It is possible this was exceeded during the heatwave of July 2019 where many other areas broke their all time records. However Leeds weather centre closed in the 2000s.

column1: As is typical for many sprawling cities in areas of varying topography
column2: temperatures can change depending on location. Average July and August daytime highs exceed 22 °C (72 °F) (a value comparable to South East England) in a small area just to the south east of the city centre
column3: where the elevation declines to under 20 metres (66 feet). This is 2 °C (3.6 °F) milder than the typical summer temperature at Leeds Bradford airport weather station (shown in the chart below)
column4: at an elevation of 208 metres (682 feet).

column1: Situated on the eastern side of the Pennines

column3: with an annual rainfall of 660 mm (25.98 in).

column1: Though extreme weather in Leeds is relatively rare

column1: Leeds is within a green belt region that extends into the wider surrounding counties and is in place to reduce urban sprawl
column2: prevent the settlements in the West Yorkshire conurbation from further convergence
column3: protect the identity of outlying communities
column4: encourage brownfield reuse
column5: and preserve nearby countryside. This is achieved by restricting inappropriate development within the designated areas
column6: and imposing stricter conditions on permitted building.Over 60% of the Leeds district is green belt land and it surrounds the settlement
column7: preventing further sprawl towards nearby communities. Larger outlying towns and villages are exempt from the green belt area. However
column9: hamlets and rural areas are 'washed over' by the designation. The green belt was first adopted in 1960

column10: and a new arcade formed by arcading Queen Victoria Street with the largest expanse of stained glass in Britain.In the Churwell area of Leeds is the White Rose Shopping Centre. Opening in 1997
column11: the centre has over 100 high street stores anchored by Debenhams
column12: Marks & Spencer
column13: Primark and Sainsbury's. Some stores have their only Leeds presence here and do not trade in Central Leeds
column14: such as the Disney Store and Build-A-Bear workshop. Although the centre is below the average typical size for out of town shopping malls like the Trafford Centre or Meadowhall in nearby Yorkshire city Sheffield
column15: it remains popular with national and international chains. Of the 40
column16: 000 people who work in retailing in Leeds 75% work in places which are not located in the city centre. There are additional shopping centres located in the many villages that became part of the county borough and in the towns that were incorporated in the City of Leeds in 1974.On 21 March 2013
column17: a large shopping and leisure complex called Trinity Leeds opened in the city centre. The modern and interactive retail space covers the old Burton Arcades and the former Leeds Shopping Plaza with its main entrance from Briggate.On 20 October 2016
column18: the newest shopping destination called Victoria Gate opened its doors to the public. The new shopping mall houses a flagship John Lewis store
column19: the largest outside London. Seventy-five per cent of the stores that opened in Victoria Gate were new to Leeds with many of those stores being the first outside of London.

column1: Leeds is home to one of the largest indoor markets in Europe
column2: Leeds Kirkgate Market. Leeds also has various regular local markets in Otley
column3: Pudsey
column4: and Yeadon.There is an annual German Christmas Market ("Christkindelmarkt") based in Millennium Square
column5: usually running from early November to mid-late December. The 2020 Christmas Market has been cancelled because of the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: Leeds displays a variety of natural and built landmarks. Natural landmarks include such diverse sites as the gritstone outcrop of Otley Chevin and the Fairburn Ings RSPB reserve. The city's parks at Roundhay and Temple Newsam have long been owned and maintained by the council for the benefit of ratepayers and among the open spaces in the centre of Leeds are Millennium Square
column2: City Square
column3: Park Square and Victoria Gardens. This last is the site of the central city war memorial: there are 42 other war memorials in the suburbs
column4: towns and villages in the district. On 14 June 2020
column5: thousands of people gathered in Millennium Square to show support for the Black Lives Matter movement with peaceful protest.The built environment embraces edifices of civic pride like Morley Town Hall and the trio of buildings in Leeds
column6: Leeds Town Hall
column7: Corn Exchange and Leeds City Museum by the architect Cuthbert Brodrick. The two white buildings on the Leeds skyline are the Parkinson building of Leeds University and the Civic Hall
column8: with golden owls adorning the tops of the latter's twin spires.Armley Mills
column9: Tower Works
column11: and the Egyptian-style Temple Works hark back to the city's industrial past
column12: while the site and ruins of Kirkstall Abbey display the beauty and grandeur of Cistercian architecture. Notable churches are Leeds Minster (formerly Leeds Parish Church)
column13: St George's Church and Leeds Cathedral
column14: in the city centre
column15: and the Church of St John the Baptist
column16: Adel and Bardsey Parish Church in quieter locations. Notable non-conformist chapels include the Salem Chapel
column17: dating back to 1791 and notably the birthplace of Leeds United Football Club in 1919.Leeds is one of only a few UK cities outside of London to have a significant number of high-rise buildings
column18: the 112-metre (367 ft) tower of Bridgewater Place
column20: is part of a major office and residential development and the region's tallest building; it can be seen for miles (kilometres) around. Bridgewater Place has been the subject of debate as its erection in 2007 caused significant wind tunnel effects
column21: channeling strong wind currents across Victoria Road. There have been numerous injuries attributed to the inadequate architecture of this building and Water Lane is frequently closed when high winds are expected. In 2017 Leeds City Council undertook construction work in an attempt to deflect the wind from street level and the building owners of Bridgewater Place agreed to pay to cover the public money being spent. Among other Skyscrapers the 37-storey Sky Plaza to the north of the city centre stands on higher ground so that its 106 metres (348 ft) is higher than Bridgewater Place.

column1: Elland Road (football) and Headingley Stadium (cricket and rugby) are well known to sports enthusiasts and the White Rose Centre is a well-known retail outlet.
Leeds' transport system is dominated by cars and it is currently the 9th most congested UK city
column2: with congestion costing £1
column3: 057 per driver.There have long been plans for a public transport network in Leeds
column4: yet as of 2020
column5: none have come to fruition. In the 1940s
column6: there were plans to build an extensive underground system
column7: however these were scuppered by the Second World War. There were plans for a Leeds Supertram in the 1990s and £500 million in funding was to be provided; however
column9: the plans were cancelled by the Transport Minister Alistair Darling in 2005
column10: even though £40 million had already been spent on the project. Hopes were renewed with the proposal for a £250 million New Generation Transport Trolleybus service in 2007; however
column11: after a long wait and millions of pounds spent on inquiries
column12: the plans were cancelled in May 2016 citing little value for money.In June 2019
column13: as part of his bid to become Prime Minister
column14: Boris Johnson stated that it was "madness" that Leeds did not have a metro system. In December 2019
column15: during his first Queen's Speech
column16: Johnson promised to "remedy the scandal that Leeds is the largest city in Western Europe without light rail or a metro".

column1: Leeds is the starting point of the A62
column4: A65 and A660 roads
column5: and is also situated on the A58 and A61. The M1 and M62 intersect to its south and the A1(M) passes to the east. Leeds is one of the principal hubs of the northern motorway network. Additionally
column6: there is an urban motorway network; the radial M621 takes traffic into central Leeds from the M62 and M1. There is an Inner Ring Road with part motorway status and an Outer Ring Road. Part of the city centre is pedestrianised
column7: and is encircled by the clockwise-only Loop Road. Construction of a major new road in the north east of the city
column9: commenced in summer 2019 with completion due by the end of 2021.

column1: Air quality in Leeds has been declared as being "unsafe" by the World Health Organisation. Neville Street
column2: near Leeds railway station
column3: has been measured as the most polluted outside London.As part of plans to tackle illegal levels of air pollution
column4: there are plans to create a Clean Air Zone in Leeds City Centre and parts of north Leeds
column5: wherein drivers will be charged a daily fee for driving "older models of buses
column6: taxis and HGVs" in these areas. The clean air zone was originally proposed in 2018 after government ordered the council to come up with ways to lower the air pollution in the city
column7: which causes around 29
column8: 000 premature deaths in the UK. This was intended to begin in January 2020
column9: but was delayed until summer 2020 and then September 2020 owing to delays in the availability of a government vehicle registration tool.  This was further delayed by the Coronavirus pandemic until "at least" 2021.

column1: Public transport in the Leeds area is coordinated and developed by West Yorkshire Metro
column2: with service information provided by Leeds City Council and West Yorkshire Metro. The primary means of public transport in Leeds are the bus services. The main provider is First Leeds and Arriva Yorkshire serves routes to the south of the city. Leeds City bus station is at Dyer Street and is used by bus services to towns and cities in Yorkshire
column3: plus a small number of local services. Adjacent to it is the coach station for National Express coach services. Buses out of the city are mainly provided by First Leeds and Arriva Yorkshire. Harrogate Bus Company provides a service to Harrogate and Ripon. Keighley Bus Company provides a service to Shipley
column4: Bingley and Keighley. The Yorkshire Coastliner service runs from Leeds to Bridlington
column5: Filey
column6: Scarborough and Whitby via York and Malton. Stagecoach in Hull provides a service to Hull via Goole. Stagecoach Yorkshire provides services to Barnsley. Also Yorkshire Tiger operates Flying Tiger services to Leeds Bradford Airport.

column1: From Leeds railway station at New Station Street
column2: West Yorkshire Metro trains operated by Northern run to Leeds' suburbs and onwards to all parts of Leeds City Region. The station is one of the busiest in England outside London
column3: with over 900 trains and 50
column4: 000 passengers passing through every day. It provides national and international connections
column5: as well as services to local and regional destinations. The station itself has 17 platforms
column6: making it the largest in England outside London.The city and metropolitan borough of Leeds is served by 16 railway stations. Plans for a parkway station serving Leeds Bradford Airport and two other new stations within the next 20 years were announced in 2016.

column1: Leeds Bradford International Airport is located in Yeadon
column2: about 8 miles (13 km) to the north-west of the city centre
column3: and has direct flights from 8 UK destinations and 70 international destinations. Scheduled services run between Leeds Bradford Airport and London Heathrow
column4: Amsterdam
column5: Dublin and Barcelona. There is also a direct rail service from Leeds to Manchester Airport.

column1: The Leeds Country Way is a waymarked circular walk of 62 miles (100 km) through the rural outskirts of the city
column2: never more than 7 miles (11 km) from City Square. The Meanwood Valley Trail leads from Woodhouse Moor along Meanwood Beck to Golden Acre Park. The Leeds extension of the Dales Way follows the Meanwood Valley Trail before it branches off to head towards Ilkley and Windermere. Leeds is on the northern section of the Trans Pennine Trail for walkers and cyclists
column3: and the towpath of the Leeds and Liverpool Canal is another popular walking and cycling route. The White Rose Way walking trail to Scarborough begins at City Square. In addition
column4: there are many parks and public footpaths in both the urban and rural parts of Leeds
column5: and The Ramblers' Association
column6: YHA and other walking organisations offer sociable walks. The Ramblers' Association publish various booklets of walks in and around Leeds.

column1: Leeds has many large parks and open spaces. Roundhay Park is the largest park in the city and is one of the largest city parks in Europe. The park has more than 700 acres (2.8 km2) of parkland
column2: lakes
column3: woodland and gardens which are all owned by Leeds City Council. Other parks in the city include: Beckett Park
column4: Bramley Fall Park
column5: Cross Flatts Park
column6: East End Park
column7: Golden Acre Park
column9: the gardens and grounds of Harewood House
column11: Meanwood Park
column12: Middleton Park
column13: Potternewton Park
column14: Pudsey Park
column15: Temple Newsam
column16: Western Flatts Park and Woodhouse Moor. There are many more smaller parks and open spaces scattered around the city
column17: which make up around 21.7% of the city's total area. A 2017 survey ranked Leeds 7th among the ten largest UK cities (by population) for the amount of green space
column18: although published comments on the survey pointed out major inconsistencies in the city boundaries used.As part of the South Bank regeneration project
column19: plans are in development for Aire Park
column20: a new 3.5 hectare city centre park located close to the former Tetley Brewery site. Planning permission for the first phase to be undertaken by Vastint UK was granted in December 2018.

column1: At the time of the 2001 census Leeds had a population of 183
column2: 000 young people aged 0–19 of whom 110
column3: 000 were attending local authority schools. In 2008 Education Leeds
column4: a non-profit company owned by Leeds City Council
column5: provided for 220 primary schools
column6: 39 secondary schools and 6 special inclusive learning centres. Under the government Building Schools for the Future initiative
column7: Leeds secured £260m to transform 13 secondary schools into high achieving
column9: inclusive schools. The first three of these schools at Allerton High School
column10: Pudsey Grangefield School and Rodillian School were opened in September 2008. The demand for primary school places in Leeds has recently hit a 15-year peak
column11: with an estimated 10
column12: 500 new starters this year. The city's oldest and largest private school is the Grammar School at Leeds
column13: which was legally re-created in 2005 following the merger of Leeds Grammar School
column14: established 1552
column15: and Leeds Girls' High School
column16: established 1876. Other independent schools in Leeds include faith schools serving the Jewish and Muslim communities.

column1: Leeds was one of a number of local authorities to try the three-tier system with first
column2: middle and secondary schools. It reverted to the two-tier system in 1992.

column1: Further education in Leeds is provided by Elliott Hudson College
column2: Leeds City College (formed by a merger in 2009 and having over 60
column3: 000 students)
column4: Leeds College of Building
column5: and Notre Dame Catholic Sixth Form College.

column2: which received its charter in 1904 having developed from the Yorkshire College which was founded in 1874 and the Leeds School of Medicine of 1831;
formerly Leeds Polytechnic

column4: and can trace its roots to the Mechanics' Institute of 1824;

formerly Leeds College of Art

column1: Northern School of Contemporary Dance;The University of Leeds has about 31
column2: 000 students

column4: 500 are full-time or sandwich undergraduate degree students

column2: Leeds embarked on a five-year cultural investment programme
column3: culminating in a year of cultural celebration in 2023. In 2023 the city will hold an international cultural festival which will harness the energy
column4: creativity and momentum of the bid to be European Capital of Culture 2023
column5: a title the city forwent following the United Kingdom's vote to leave the European Union.

column1: Although the city's municipal art gallery (Leeds Art Gallery) did not open until 1888
column2: art practice and collecting has a long history in Leeds. J. M. W. Turner painted numerous scenes in and around the city
column3: and the city was home to one of Britain's largest collections of Pre-Raphaelite Art
column4: owned by Thomas Plint
column5: during the nineteenth century. There was also an early history of holding large-scale public exhibitions in the city
column6: most notably the series of 'Polytechnic Exhibitions' held regularly from 1839.Leeds produced many notable artists and sculptors
column7: including Kenneth Armitage
column9: Jacob Kramer
column11: Henry Moore
column12: Edward Wadsworth and Joash Woodrow
column13: and was the centre for a particularly radical strain of British art. Before the First World War Leeds was the home of an unusual modernist arts organisation
column14: called the Leeds Arts Club
column15: founded by Alfred Orage
column16: which lasted from 1903 to 1923. Notable members included Jacob Kramer
column18: Frank Rutter and Michael Sadler. As well as advocating a radical political agenda
column20: the Independent Labour Party and the Fabian Society
column21: and promoting the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche
column22: the Leeds Arts Club was almost unique in Britain as being an exponent of German Expressionist ideas about art and culture. As a result
column23: it staged very early British exhibitions of work by European expressionist artists
column25: showing their work in the city as early as 1913
column26: and produced its own English Expressionist artists
column27: including Jacob Kramer and Bruce Turner.In the 1920s Leeds College of Art was the starting point for the careers of the sculptors Barbara Hepworth and Henry Moore
column29: and 1960s it was one of the leading centres for radical art education in Britain under the guidance of artists such as Harry Thubron and Tom Hudson
column30: and the art historian Norbert Lynton. Their attempts to redefine what art education should mean in the post-Second World War period led the artist Patrick Heron to claim in 1971 in The Guardian newspaper that "Leeds is the most influential art school in Europe since the Bauhaus". This willingness to push at the boundaries of acceptable public behaviour from artists was also evident in 1966 when Leeds College of Art staged an exhibition of paintings by the Cypriot artist Stass Paraskos
column32: which was raided by the police after allegations of obscenity.This radicalism continued into the 1970s when the higher education component of Leeds College of Art was split from the college to form the nucleus of the new multidisciplinary Leeds Polytechnic
column33: now called Leeds Beckett University. Performance art had been taught earlier at Leeds College of Art
column34: notably by the Fluxus artist Robin Page during his time as a tutor there in the mid-1960s
column35: but in 1977 a performance art work hit the national news headlines when the students Pete Parkin and Derek Wain used an air pistol to shoot a line up of live budgerigars in front of an audience at Leeds Polytechnic.The University of Leeds was the alma mater of Herbert Read
column36: one of the leading international theorists of modern art from the mid-twentieth century
column37: and also the teaching base for the Marxist art historian Arnold Hauser from 1951 to 1985. Partly due to Herbert Read's connection with the University
column38: from 1950 to 1970 the University was the host of one of the first artist-in-residence schemes in Britain
column39: using funding from the then owner of Lund Humphries books
column42: were given to painters and sculptors for up to two years to allow them to develop their own work and influence the University in any way they saw fit. Amongst those holding the fellowships were Kenneth Armitage
column44: Dennis Creffield and Terry Frost and others. Parallel Gregory Fellowships also existed in music and poetry at the University.Leeds was also a centre for radical feminist art
column45: with one of the first galleries in Britain dedicated to showing the work of women photographers
column48: and the University of Leeds School of Fine Art being a well-known centre for the development of feminist art history
column50: during the 1980s and 1990s. Possibly as a result of the strength of feminist art in Leeds
column51: in November 1984 an exhibition of ceramics by students and staff at Leeds Polytechnic was attacked by a group of feminist activists who destroyed eight sculptures on display which they deemed to be degrading to women. The University of Leeds's School of Fine Art also specialised in Art & Language conceptual art practice
column53: again in the 1980s and 1990s.A major sculpture research centre and gallery
column55: is located alongside Leeds Art Gallery in the city centre
column56: and in 2013 a new contemporary art centre
column58: opened on the site of the former Tetley Brewery to the south of the city centre.

column2: The Times voted Leeds as the number one cultural place to live in Britain. This was ahead of London
column3: Birmingham
column4: St Ives
column5: Stratford-upon-Avon and Cheltenham. The citation notes that Leeds has Opera North
column6: the Northern Ballet
column7: and the Leeds Playhouse amongst many other attractions that ranked it at number one.

column1: Leeds West Indian Carnival is Western Europe's oldest West Indian Carnival
column2: and the UK's third-largest after the Notting Hill and Nottingham Carnival. It attracts around 100
column3: 000 people over 2 days to the streets of Chapeltown and Harehills. There is a large procession that finishes at Potternewton Park
column4: where there are stalls
column5: entertainment and refreshments. The Leeds Festival
column6: featuring some of the biggest names in rock and indie music
column7: takes place every year in Bramham Park. The Leeds Asian Festival
column9: is held in Roundhay Park. The Otley Folk Festival (patron: Nic Jones)
column11: Carnival and Victorian Christmas Fayre are annual events. Light Night Leeds takes place each October
column12: and many venues in the city are open to the public for Heritage Open Days in September. The Leeds International Pianoforte Competition
column13: established in 1963 by Fanny Waterman and Marion Stein
column14: has been held in the city every three years since 1963 and has launched the careers of many major concert pianists. The Leeds International Concert Season
column15: which includes orchestral and choral concerts in Leeds Town Hall and other events
column16: is the largest local authority music programme in the UK.The Leeds International Film Festival is the largest film festival in England outside London and shows films from around the world. It incorporates the highly successful Leeds Young People's Film Festival
column17: which features exciting and innovative films made both for and by children and young people. Garforth is host to the fortnight-long festival The Garforth Arts Festival which has been an annual event since 2005. The Chapel Allerton Arts Festival is a week-long music and arts event starting in 1998 and held the week after August Bank Holiday each year.

column1: The Leeds Festival Fringe is a week long-music festival created in 2010 to showcase local talent in the week prior to Leeds Festival.

column2: one of the UK's largest annual arts and light festivals
column3: is a huge fixture on the calendar
column4: taking place in the first week of October
column5: turning the entire city into an art installation with light shows
column6: projections
column7: installations and lots more.Leeds Pride is an annual LGBT+ festival held since 2006 supported by the city council and local business. In 2018 attendance was 40
column8: 000 with over 100 floats and benefits the city by over £3.8 million. The city has a sponsorship scheme for its 15 Rainbow Plaques commemorating places and events that are of significance to the LGBT+ community organised through Leeds Civic Trust.Other festivals include Transform and Thought Bubble.

column1: In October 1888 Louis Le Prince filmed moving picture sequences Roundhay Garden Scene and a Leeds Bridge street scene using his single-lens camera and Eastman's paper film. These were several years before the work of competing inventors such as Auguste and Louis Lumière and Thomas Edison.

column2: Leeds International Film Festival's International Short Film Competition is named after Louis Le Prince. The 2015 documentary film The First Film
column3: which first aired at the Edinburgh International Film Festival
column4: documents Le Prince's pioneering status.Wordsworth Donisthorpe who was also from Leeds
column5: filmed the second-oldest-surviving film. It is not known if he and Louis Le Prince ever met but they both had a strong connection to the Leeds Philosophical and Literary Society. Donisthorpe's patent for a camera to capture the moving image pre dated Le Prince's by twelve years.Leeds has a rich film exhibition culture. In addition to the Leeds International Film Festival and Leeds Young Film Festival
column6: the city hosts numerous independent cinemas and pop-up venues for film screenings. The Cottage Road Cinema and Hyde Park Picture House have continuously been showing films since 1912 and 1914
column7: respectively
column8: which ranks them among the oldest still-running cinemas in the UK.

column1: Leeds has produced many writers of note
column2: including celebrated author and playwright Alan Bennett.  J. R. R. Tolkien
column3: author of The Lord of the Rings
column4: lived and taught in Leeds from 1921 to 1925.Leeds Central Library
column5: the city's public library is located on Calverley Street
column6: near many of Leeds' other municipal buildings. The Leeds Library in Commercial Street is a private subscription library
column7: and the oldest surviving library of this kind in the UK. The British Library houses a significant portion of its collection just outside Boston Spa
column8: a village within the City of Leeds. The Boston Spa location is home to the library's newspaper archive
column9: which contains over 20 million items. The library also plans to open a facility in Leeds City Centre
column10: potentially in the Grade I listed Temple Works in the South Bank area.In 2019 and 2020
column11: Leeds hosted the Leeds Lit Fest
column12: a "non-traditional" literature festival
column13: incorporating talks
column14: panels & workshops.There are plans to create a National Poetry Centre in Leeds.

column2: owned by Johnston Press plc
column3: is based in the city

column5: The Yorkshire Post
column6: and an evening paper

column9: published in Ilkley

column12: the weekly Leeds Student from the University of Leeds and the monthly The Met from Leeds Beckett University. The Leeds Guide was a fortnightly listings magazine

column2: in addition to Channel 4 having recently announced that their national HQ will be located in Leeds. ITV Yorkshire
column3: formerly Yorkshire Television

column9: Capital Yorkshire

column1: Made in Leeds is a local television station which launched across the city in 2014. A privately owned television station: Leeds Television is run by volunteers and supported by professionals in the media industry.
Leeds has over 16 museums and galleries including 9 that are council-run.
A new Leeds City Museum opened in 2008 in Millennium Square. Leeds's major museum
column2: it showcases the city's designated collections of local history
column3: world cultures
column4: natural history
column5: archaeology and fine and decorative arts plus a diverse programme of special exhibitions.

column3: childhood
column4: and Victorian Leeds.

column3: by Louis Le Prince
column4: of a Roundhay Garden Scene and of Leeds Bridge in 1888. These short film clips can be found on YouTube.

column1: Thwaite Mills Watermill Museum is a fully restored 1820s water-powered mill on the River Aire to the east of the city centre.
The Thackray Museum is a museum of the history of medicine

column3: pre-anaesthesia surgery
column4: and safety in childbirth. It is housed in a former workhouse next to St James's Hospital.

column2: the United Kingdom's national collection of arms and armour

column1: Nearby is the Leeds Museum Discovery Centre (formerly housed at the Leeds Museum Resource Centre in Yeadon)

theatre and dance ===

column1: Leeds is home to the refurbished Grand Theatre where the only national opera company outside London
column2: Opera North
column3: is based. The City Varieties Music Hall is one of the UK's few remaining music halls
column4: and famously hosted performances by Charlie Chaplin and Harry Houdini. It was also the venue of the BBC television programme The Good Old Days. The newest theatre
column5: containing two auditoriums

column9: who were formed in the Harehills area of the city in 1981
column10: and Northern Ballet Theatre. In autumn 2010 the two companies moved into a purpose-built dance centre which is the largest space for dance outside London. It is also the only space for dance to house a national classical and a national contemporary dance company alongside each another.The First Direct Arena opened in September 2013. The 13

column1: The F Club was club night that ran in Leeds between 1977 and 1982 and specialised in punk rock and post-punk. It would prove highly influential to the development of the goth subculture
column2: due to it leading to the formation of seminal gothic rock bands like The Sisters of Mercy
column3: The March Violets and Southern Death Cult. The now-defunct club Le Phonographique was located in the Merrion Centre and was the first gothic nightclub in the world.Leeds has a well established LGBT+ nightlife scene
column4: predominantly located in the Freedom Quarter on Lower Briggate. The New Penny is one of the UK's longest running LGBT+ venues
column5: and Leeds oldest gay bar. The Viaduct Showbar holds drag cabaret
column6: live shows and DJs. Other places include The Bridge
column7: Blayds Bar

column1: Popular areas for nightlife in Leeds include Call Lane
column2: Briggate and the Arena Quarter. Towards Millennium Square is a growing entertainment district providing for both students and weekend visitors. The square has many bars and restaurants and a large outdoor screen. Millennium Square is a venue for large seasonal events such as a Christmas market
column3: gigs and concerts
column4: and citywide parties. It is adjacent to the Mandela Gardens
column5: which were opened by Nelson Mandela in 2001. A number of public art features
column6: fountains
column7: and greenery can be found here.

column1: Yorkshire has a great history of real ale
column2: but several bars near the railway station are fusing traditional beers with a modern bar. Popular bars such as this include The Hop
column3: The Cross Keys and The Brewery Tap. Leeds also hosts an annual Leeds International Beer Festival
column4: held at Leeds Town Hall every September.

column1: The city has teams representing all the major national sports. Leeds United F.C. is the city's main football club
column2: additional clubs include Guiseley AFC and Farsley Celtic.

column1: Leeds United was formed in 1919 and plays at the 37
column2: 890-capacity Elland Road Stadium in Beeston. The team will play in the Premier League for the first time in sixteen years after they won promotion by winning the EFL Championship in 2019–20.

column1: Guiseley was formed in 1909 and plays at the 4
column2: 000 capacity Nethermoor Park Stadium in Guiseley. The team plays in the National League North they won promotion to the National League for the first time ever in 2014/15 after beating Chorley 2–3.

column1: Farsley Celtic was formed in 1908 and plays in the National League North and their stadium is Throstle Nest.
Leeds Rhinos are the most successful rugby league team in Leeds. In 2009
column2: they became first club to be Super League champions three seasons running
column3: giving them their fourth Super League title.

column1: They play their home games at the Headingley Rugby Stadium. Hunslet
column2: based at the John Charles Centre for Sport
column3: play in the Co-Operative Championship One. East Leeds and Oulton Raiders play in the National Conference League. Bramley Buffaloes (previously Bramley)
column4: and Leeds Akkies were members of the Rugby League Conference.

column1: Leeds Tykes are the foremost rugby union team in Leeds and they previously also played at Headingley. They play in National League 1 having been relegated from RFU Championship at the end of the 2019–20 season. Otley RUFC are a rugby union club based to the north of the city and compete in National League 2 North
column2: whilst Morley RFC
column3: located in Morley currently play in National Division Three North.

column1: Headingley Cricket Stadium is home to Yorkshire County Cricket Club which is the most successful cricket team in England
column2: with 33 County Championship wins (including one shared). Their main rivals are Lancashire.

column1: Leeds City Athletic Club competes in the British Athletics League and UK Women's League as well as the Northern Athletics League.
Leeds is home to a number of field hockey clubs that compete in the North Hockey League
column2: Yorkshire Hockey Association League and BUCS leagues. These include Leeds Hockey Club
column3: Leeds Adel Carnegie Hockey Club
column4: the University of Leeds Hockey Club and Leeds Beckett University Hockey Club.

column1: Leeds Hockey Club Men's 1s gained promotion at the end of the 2016/2017 season to become Leeds's first hockey team competing in a National League.The City of Leeds Synchronised Swimming Club train at the John Charles Centre for Sport and are represented by swimmers throughout the whole of the North East. The club was founded in 2008 and only compete in National and International Competition.
The city has a wealth of sports facilities including the Elland Road football stadium
column2: a host stadium during the 1996 European Football Championship; the Headingley Carnegie Stadiums
column3: adjacent stadia world-famous for both cricket and rugby league and the John Charles Centre for Sport with an Olympic-sized pool in its Aquatics Centre and includes a multi-use stadium. Other facilities include the Leeds Wall (climbing) and Yeadon Tarn sailing centre. In 1929 the first Ryder Cup of Golf to be held on British soil was competed for at the Moortown Golf club in Leeds and Wetherby has a National Hunt racecourse. In the period 1928 to 1939 speedway racing was staged in Leeds on a track at the greyhound stadium known as Fullerton Park
column4: adjacent to Elland Road. The track entered a team in the 1931 Northern league.

column1: The 2014 Tour de France Grand Départ took place from the Headrow in Leeds city centre on 5 July 2014.
Leeds is well known for its divers and features some of the best diving facilities in the UK. City of Leeds Diving Club
column2: who train at the John Charles Centre for Sport
column3: has trained many athletes who have competed at international and Olympic level
column4: with Jack Laugher and Chris Mears making history by becoming the first ever divers from Great Britain to win an Olympic gold medal
column5: a feat they accomplished at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

column1: Leeds has an ice hockey team
column2: the Leeds Chiefs; they play at the Planet Ice Arena in Beeston
column3: Leeds in the National Ice Hockey League.

column1: The majority of people in Leeds identify themselves as Christian. Leeds does not have a Church of England Cathedral: it is in the Anglican Diocese of Leeds (formerly in the Diocese of Ripon and Leeds)
column2: headed by the Bishop of Leeds
column3: which has cathedrals in Bradford
column4: Ripon and Wakefield although the Bishop's residence has been in Leeds since 2008. The most important Anglican church is Leeds Minster
column5: although St. George's has the largest congregation by far. Leeds has a Roman Catholic Cathedral
column6: the episcopal seat of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Leeds. Many other Christian denominations and new religious movements are established in Leeds
column7: including Assemblies of God
column9: Christian Scientist
column11: Community of Christ
column12: Greek Orthodox
column13: Jehovah's Witnesses
column14: Jesus Army
column15: Lutheran
column16: Methodist
column28: Winners' Chapel and several independent churches.

column1: The proportion of Muslims in Leeds is slightly above average for the country (5.4% as of 2011). Mosques can be found throughout the city
column2: serving Muslim communities in Chapeltown
column3: Harehills
column4: Hyde Park and parts of Beeston. The largest mosque is Leeds Grand Mosque in Hyde Park.

column1: The Sikh community is represented by gurdwaras (temples) spread across the city
column2: the largest being in Chapeltown. There is also a colourful religious annual procession
column3: called the Nagar Kirtan
column4: into Millennium Square in the city centre on 13–14 April to celebrate Vaisakhi—the Sikh New Year and the birth of the religion. It is estimated that around 3
column5: 000 Sikhs in Leeds take part in this annual event.

column1: Leeds's Jewish community is the third-largest in the United Kingdom
column2: after London and Greater Manchester. The areas of Alwoodley and Moortown contain sizeable Jewish populations. There are eight active synagogues in Leeds.The Hindu community in Leeds has a temple (mandir) at Hyde Park. The temple has all the major Hindu deities and is dedicated to the Lord Mahavira of the Jains.Various Buddhist traditions are represented in Leeds
column3: including: Soka Gakkai
column4: Theravada
column5: Tibetan
column6: Triratna Buddhist Community and Zen. The Buddhist community (sangha) comes together to celebrate the major festival of Wesak in May.

column1: There is also a community of the Bahá'í Faith in Leeds.
Water supply and sewerage services in Leeds are provided by Yorkshire Water
column2: part of the Kelda Group. Prior to 1973 water and sewerage services had been provided by the Leeds Corporation. Leeds City Council has a target of 11MW of renewable energy from onshore wind by 2010 and an aspirational target of 75MW by 2020. There are currently no operational wind farms in Leeds
column3: but a planning application by Banks Renewables Ltd for five turbines at Hook Moor near Micklefield was approved in 2011.

column1: The area is policed by the West Yorkshire Police. The force has five policing districts covering the West Yorkshire area
column2: one of which covers Leeds. The Leeds District Headquarters is located at Elland Road in the south of the city. In the north-west of the city the main stations are Weetwood and Woodhouse Lane; in the north-east
column3: the main stations are Stainbeck near Chapel Allerton and Killingbeck; in the south the main stations are Leeds Central
column4: located on Park Street in the city centre
column5: and the District Headquarters itself. Fire and rescue services are provided by the West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service. The fire stations in Leeds are: Cookridge
column6: Gipton
column7: Hunslet
column9: Moortown
column10: Stanningley and the "Leeds" fire station (near the city centre
column11: on Kirkstall Road).

column1: NHS health services are provided by the Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust
column2: Leeds Primary Care Trust  and Leeds and York Partnership NHS Foundation Trust
column3: which provides mental health services. Leeds General Infirmary ("LGI") is a listed building with more recent additions and is in the city centre. St James's University Hospital
column4: known locally as "Jimmy's"
column5: is to the north east of the city centre and is the largest teaching hospital in Europe. Other NHS hospitals are Chapel Allerton Hospital
column6: Seacroft Hospital
column7: Wharfedale Hospital in Otley
column8: and Leeds Dental Institute. The new NHS Leeds Website provides information on NHS services in Leeds.West Yorkshire Joint Services provides analytical
column9: archaeological
column11: ecology
column12: materials testing and trading standards services in Leeds and the other four districts of West Yorkshire. It was created following the abolition of the county council in 1986 and expanded in 1997
column13: and is funded by the five district councils
column14: pro rata to their population. The Leeds site of the archives service is in the former public library at Sheepscar
column15: Leeds.Leeds City Council is responsible for over 50 public libraries across the whole city
column16: including 5 mobile libraries. The main Central Library is located on the Headrow in the city centre.

column1: The following people and military units have received the Freedom of the City of Leeds.
Field Marshal Rt Hon Lord Haig : 23 January 1920.
Admiral of the Fleet Rt Hon Lord Beatty : 18 October 1922.
Rt Hon David Lloyd George : 21 October 1922.
Rt Hon H. V. Evatt : 7 July 1943.
Rt Hon Sir Winston Churchill : 28 October 1958.
Major Rt Hon Lord Milner of Leeds : 1967.
51st (2nd Yorkshire West Riding) Regiment of Foot
